snippet: China’s domestic economic balance is precarious, the International Monetary Fund said, largely because of too little consumer spending and too much government spending.
abstract: International Monetary Fund says China’s domestic economic balance is precarious, largely because of too little consumer spending and too much government spending; says country's expansion may not be sustainable unless it starts making significant economic changes soon.

byline.contributor: Bettina Wassener contributed reporting from Hong Kong.

lead_paragraph: China’s domestic economic balance is precarious, the International Monetary Fund said, largely because of too little consumer spending and too much government spending.

headline.main: I.M.F. Tells China of Urgent Need for Economic Change
headline.print_headline: I.M.F. Warns of Threats To the Chinese Economy
